summary:
RHI Magnesita is the leading global supplier of high-grade refractory products, systems, and solutions that are critical for high-temperature processes exceeding 1,200°C in a wide range of industries, including steel, cement, non-ferrous metals, and glass. 

With a vertically integrated value chain, from raw materials to refractory products and full performance-based solutions, RHI Magnesita serves customers around the world, with around 12,000 employees in 28 main production sites and more than 70 sales offices. RHI Magnesita intends to leverage its leadership in terms of revenue, scale, product portfolio, and diversified geographic presence to target strategically those countries and regions benefitting from more dynamic economic growth prospects.

profile_positions.description:
I worked as a sales assistant in the IShop, the University of Groningen merchandise store.

The most common tasks include assisting the customers with purchase-related inquiries, handling the cash register, managing web orders from our online store, and maintaining the store clean and tidy. Since the "I" in IShop stands for information, I also regularly assist students, visitors and staff members of the University with inquires regarding Groningen city or the University itself.

One of the more responsible tasks that I occasionally take on as an experienced retail assistant at the IShop is training new employees to prepare them to function independently in the store. After the training is done I often assist my less experienced colleagues with their struggles or questions to increase the efficacy of the workplace team.

From time to time I also participate in photo shoots to promote our products and business.
profile_positions.title: Retail Assistant

profile_positions.description:
As a Career Services Student Advisor for the Career Services at the University of Groningen I was responsible for an array of various tasks ascribed to a student assistant. 

My main responsibilities included representing the Career Services across the University of Groningen, and giving career-related advice to undergraduate and graduate students at our university; this included giving feedback on CV/resumes, cover/motivation letters, or LinkedIn profiles. Occasionally I would also conduct mock job interviews with students who had a real interview coming or answering career-related inquiries in person during events or online via email. 

Between September 2020 and March 2022 I also became a trainer for career-related workshops on topics such as self-analysis or personal branding in the employment context, networking, etc. During that time I gave close to 40 workshops and moderated more than 10 workshops lead by another trainer. 

Some other tasks that I did for the Career Services between September 2019 and September 2020 include but are not limited to, managing the organization's social media Instagram account (careerservices_ug) and organizing a career event for students (Career Opportunities at the EU, 28th May 2020).
profile_positions.title: Career Services Student Advisor

profile_positions.description:
Small group (3 groups of 12 students, 2 groups in academic year 2019/2020 and 1 group in academic year 2020/2021) peer-mentoring, without the direct supervision of a faculty staff mentor. 

During this student assistant position I was fully responsible for teaching and coordinating the group dynamics within the practical groups of a second year course - Communication and Diagnostic Skills.  

My main duties as a peer-mentor included session preparation (based on main learning points from the syllabus), active presentation of the material to the students, as well as assessing and grading student papers and their in-class participation. 

Aside from that, to ensure the appropriate dynamics within the groups, I had to occasionally resolve intragroup conflicts or provide personal guidance to struggling students. 

Through this experience I have gained thorough theoretical and practical insights into various teaching techniques and knowledge of how to improvise in and overcome unexpected situations.
profile_positions.title: Student Mentor for Communication and Diagnostic Skills (and Working with Psychology) course

profile_positions.description:
As an International Alumni Ambassador I had the pleasure to actively network with other University of Groningen graduates, from all over the world, who are in different stages of their studies and lives.

In this position I had the opportunity to represent the University of Groningen and help prospective students with their journey of becoming a fellow student.

A vital part of the program was developing my interpersonal abilities such as presentation or networking skills, as well as apprehending how to build a strong and influential brand image.
profile_positions.title: Alumni Ambassador Program

profile_positions.description:
Small group (2 groups of 12 students) peer-mentoring under the supervision of a faculty staff mentor, on a first-year course in the Bachelor's degree in Psychology - Academic Skills. 

The course gave an overview of the academically relevant skills such as scientific literature understanding and interpretation, critical thinking, scientific writing (APA formatting) or academic presentation (in form of oral or PowerPoint presentation). 

Through this experience I gained confidence in small-group leadership and self-presentation skills, as well as developed further my time and task organizational skills.
profile_positions.title: Student Mentor for Academic Skills course

profile_positions.description:
Qualitative research in the field of Human Geography and Spatial Sciences for an EU-wide project "IMAJINE", where 30-60 minute interviews were conducted with Polish work immigrants, living in the Netherlands. 

The aim of the interviews was to gather information about the life of Polish immigrants, working in the Netherlands. The topics during the interviews entailed sensitive topics such as stigma and exclusion from the Dutch society, reasons for immigration or earnings in the destination country as compared to the motherland Poland. Other topics of a less sensitive nature were for example differences between the quality of life in the Netherlands and Poland, the type of life the immigrants lead in the host country or their perspectives for the future.

Apart from conducting the interviews I was also responsible for field participant acquisition, as well as bilingual interviews transcription (from Polish to English).

Through this experience my qualitative research skills and time/task management skills were developed, because I was fully responsible for delivering the final outcome (transcribed interviews) with very minimal supervision during the task.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
This position as a student mentor for the first-year practical course Introduction to Research Methods gave me a good overview of the methods used in Psychological research. 

My role was to lead and facilitate small group (2 groups of 12 students) peer-mentoring sessions, where students completed assignments related to various research methods (mostly quantitative but also a few qualitative) used in Psychology. 

Through teaching this course I was able to consolidate my knowledge about the basic Psychological research terms and methods, as well as good and bad research practices.


The experience of peer-mentorship additionally gave me confidence in leading research-oriented discussions. It also increased my capacity to find new ways to explain confusing research concepts to those with a hard time understanding them.
profile_positions.title: Student Mentor for Introduction to Research Skills
